w:r.w:t: . male with history notable for sensory processing disorder, chronic hoarseness now resolved, and

reflux, who presented with a history of prolonged fever, strawberry tongue, rash and possibly conjunctivitis. The fever and rash started on 10/26 although they report his fever to be low grade which they did not measure and he had normal energy. The rash began on his back and then extended to his face and trunk but is now resolving. High fevers started on 11/1 with fevers to 102 accompanied by irritability and tiredness (he only stayed in be

d). Therefore this is either his 8th or 12th day of illness. He had some red lips without notable lip cracking, but did have perioral lesions. He has had perioral lesions previously with all types of illnesses, which are possibly herpetic and are crusted over at this time. Parents indicate some

desquamation of his toes the last few days. He has had a strawberry tongue for the past week which has started to improve. The parents saw their PMD three times during the course of illness. On Nov. 1 or thereabouts
had a positive rapid strep test and was started on an antibiotic which the parents think is
which he is now on day #7.

At the time of admission his conjunctivitis was much improved per parents compared to day prior. His fever had remitted x 1-2 days. His tongue was improving, as was his rash. They indicate his tiredness/irritability was worst from Nov 1-4 but is now much improved.

He has been lethargic and vomited 4x on 11/1 and 1x yesterday. He has also had a cough for 2 weeks. Sick contacts include his family members who all currently have symptoms of URI. Parents deny any changes in appetite or bowel habits. No diarrhea, no dysuria. The patient was seen by his PMD on 11/2 with positive strep culture and was prescribed

(now day 7). The rash seemed to improve slightly with antibiotics, though the patient remained somewhat tired and irritable. Today, the parents report that the patient's tiredness seems much improved and that he is more active. He had been getting
x 10 days PRN for fever and HA.
. Hispanic female who is previously healthy who presents with 6 days of fever.
was well until last Wednesday (6 days ago) when she started having decreased activity and a low grade fever. On Thursday mom noted

left neck was red and swollen so she took her to the PMD. She was told she had an infection and was started on Keflex. She did have some stomach pain this day although mom attributed this to constipation. Patient took
, had a good bowel movement with some "pellets" and then was pain free. Thursday night she spiked a fever to 101.5. Mom gave her
which only helped a little bit, and patient's appetite

decreased. Through the weekend patient continued to have fevers daily, worst at night with more irritability and decreased appetite evenings more than mornings. Her neck became more painful and the "bump" on the left stayed stable throughout the weekend. Mom noted during fevers that the patient's feet were very warm and she would put ice packs on her ankles. Temp over the weekend was around 102.4 per mom and she started noticing dry cracked lips. One day prior to admission mom noted patient woke up with red bilateral eyes and a rash on her arms legs and buttocks that was red and splotchy in nature. At this point she spiked to her highest temp of 103.4. The rash has since resolved but now appears on her feet bilaterally. She has one bout of emesis this morning NBNB but no diarrhea. Her eyes have stayed red and neck has stayed painful. Mom thinks her hands may be a little bit swollen. Given the new symptoms mom took Alexandra back to the doctor who told her to go the
ED. She has complained of headache for the 4 days prior to admission.
Prior, to admission, the child was evaluated at the ED where KD labs. The decision was made to admit to the
Children's Hospital KD inpatient service for IVIG treatment.
This is a 3-year-old otherwise healthy child with a 5-day history of fever,
, dry lips and then a rash that started on the trunk and
spread quite diffusely. Was seen by the PMD on the day of admission who
some labs and checked a rapid Strep which was negative. However, the
PMD decided to continue on with amoxicillin for a possible pharyngitis. Mom
that the patient really did not tolerate the amoxicillin and spit up
2 doses she tried to give him. She reports the patient has had no
, no abnormal or red tongue, but she has noticed that his hands
feet are swollen. She also states on the day of admission the patient
complained of some dysuria and has had somewhat decreased urine output
very well. There has been a sick contact
the house which is the 8-year-old sister. She was recently tested for
and treated with the Zithromax, although she ended up not having

a 6 year old African American male, with no significant past medical history who presents with lymphadenopathy, fever, throat pain, and irritability for 5 days. Mother initially noticed patient’s neck was swollen on Wednesday (5 days prior to admission), and then the

having fevers and a sore throat as well. Mother took him to Urgent Care 3 days ago where he was diagnosed with lymphadenitis and started on Clindamycin and Tylenol #3 for pain. Patient’s symptoms continued to worsen so mother brought him to the ED today.

was 103.3 this morning. Neck is more swollen, L>R, today. He reports the pain is getting worse. Patient has also recently had a headache. Mother reports today that his eyes are red and the right one has been slightly painful. Patient also has a painful red rash in his groin area, no exudates, flat,
-pruritic. Patient is still drinking, although has a decreased appetite. Patient has been more irritable. No cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation.
In the ED, patient was given an IVF bolus of 10mg/kg, acetaminophen and ibuprofen for fever, and Dr. Burns was contact regarding the working diagnosis of Kawasaki Disease.

male who has a past medical history significant for premature delivery at 32 weeks with NICU stay, who presents with three days of fever, rash and fussiness. Mother states that about 5 days ago, Kyle was becoming

and had low grade temperature of 99. Two days prior to presentation (Tuesday 6/5), he woke up with a fine, red rash over most of his body and had a temperature of 102, so she presented to her PMD. While there he was diagnosed with scarlet fever after having a rapid strep test and prescribed Amoxicillin. The fever has continued the past few days, up to 102-103, so they decided to come to ED for further

evaluation. Mother says he has been fussy, and has had nasal congestion and cough. He has had decreased PO intake of solids but has been breast feeding more frequently and only had decreased number of wet diapers today. His hands and feet have seemed swollen and
to the parents, and they say that his lips and mouth seem more red. They deny
injection or swollen lymph nodes. He has not had any sick contacts. He has had soft stools for the past few days, up to 4 a day, when usually he only has one bowel movement.
In our ED, suspicion for Kawasaki disease, although only has had three days of fever, and only some criteria.
Dr. Burns was contacted who recommended labs, which show elevated AST, ALT and GGT. He was accepted by KD team for admission for further workup to rule out KD.

. male in previously good health who was sent to the ED by outside provider for suspected Kawasaki disease. Seven days ago, on 3/1/2012, Prince began showing cold symptoms of rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, hoarse voice, congestion, and cough. Five days ago Prince developed fever, and the next day his eyes were a little red. Three days ago when he broke out in a rash on his arms and legs, he was taken to PMD where he was diagnosed with scarlet fever by rapid strep test and prescribed Amoxicillin. His rash and conjunctivitis got worse the next day despite treatment and yesterday he developed chapped lips. This morning he was taken to a follow up appointment for his diagnosis of scarlet fever where he was seen by a provider new to this patient who instructed mother to have the patient evaluated for Kawasaki Disease.
Per mother the patient's rash is now much improved from

original presentation and the fevers which peaked at 101.8 were well controlled with ibuprofen. There has been no change in appetite, but his nose has required frequent suctioning during feeding due to congestion. He has also been rubbing his eyes frequently since his illness started last Thursday. He has had no peeling of the skin and no rash on the trunk of his body. There has been no vomiting, diarrhea, or change in urination and stooling habits.
